unnormalised: Okay, here's the blog post about Indian Airways, designed to be conversational and contain various unnormalized elements, as requested.
normalised: So, you are planning a trip within India, huh? Awesome! But navigating the world of Indian Airways can be a bit… well, let us just say “interesting.” I have flown domestically more times than I can count (seriously, ask my travel agent!), and I have learned a few things along the way. Figured I would share some of my hard-earned wisdom, especially if you are a first-timer. Think of this as your “Indian Airways Survival Guide.”

normalised: First things first: booking. I usually check prices on sites like MakeMyTrip or Yatra dot com. You will see options from Indigo, SpiceJet, Air India, and Vistara (they merged, B-T-W, effective first january two thousand and twenty four, I think). Keep an eye out for deals, especially during off-season. Airlines often have flash sales, but they disappear faster than my patience at airport security. Pro-tip: booking forty five days in advance often gets you the best fares.

normalised: Now, about those fares… Do not be fooled by the initial low price. It is like seeing a vada pav for rupee ten and then realizing you need to pay extra for the chutney. Airlines love to add on charges. Baggage is a big one. Indigo charges approximately rupee four hundred extra if you exceed the fifteen kilogram check-in limit. And meals? Forget about gourmet dining. Pack some snacks – trust me on this. Unless you are flying Vistara, which offers slightly better grub, but at a premium.

normalised: Speaking of baggage, be prepared for some chaos at the check-in counters. Queues can be long, especially at peak times like six zero zero A-M or during Diwali holidays. And then there is the weighing. They are super strict! Even a kilo over can cost you. I once saw a guy unpack his entire suitcase at the counter, trying to redistribute the weight. It was… a sight. Do not be that guy. Invest in a luggage scale (they are like, rupee five hundred on Amazon).

normalised: Security is another adventure. Remember, no power banks over twenty thousand M-A-H in your checked baggage. Also, they might ask you to remove your shoes, belt, and any electronic devices. The drill is pretty standard, but the lines can be unpredictable. Just breathe and remember that chai at the other end.

normalised: Once you are on the plane, well… it is a domestic flight. Do not expect the luxury of Emirates. Legroom is usually tight (especially if you are six feet like my bhai), and the in-flight entertainment is limited. Download some movies or podcasts beforehand. Noise-canceling headphones are a lifesaver. And yes, the announcements are usually in Hindi, English, and then some regional language.

normalised: Finally, arrival. Getting off the plane is usually the quickest part. Claiming your baggage? That is where the real test of patience begins. It can take anywhere from fifteen minutes to forty five minutes for the bags to appear. And there is always that moment of panic when you think your suitcase is lost. But hey, that is all part of the Indian flying experience, right? Just remember to keep calm, carry on, and prepone your return flight, so you do not miss the preponed preponement! Happy travels!
